metadata.title: Under the Greenwood Tree
metadata.subject: English
metadata.description: A song by William Shakespeare from the play 'As You Like It'. The song invites those who have given up ambition and worldly pursuits to come live a simple, free life in the forest, singing to the birds, with no enemy but winter and rough weather.

preAssessment.question: From which play is the song 'Under the Greenwood Tree' taken?
What does the old English word 'hither' mean?
Who is invited in the song to come under the greenwood tree?
options: B) Those who have given up ambition

preAssessment.question: According to the song, what is the only enemy in the greenwood forest life?

concepts.title: Shakespeare and 'As You Like It'
concepts.content: William Shakespeare (1564â€“1616) is widely considered the greatest writer in the English language. He wrote 37 plays, 154 sonnets, and many poems. 'As You Like It' is one of his famous comedies, written around 1599. The play is set partly in the Forest of Arden, a magical place where characters who have been unfairly treated in court (real life) escape to live freely and honestly. 'Under the Greenwood Tree' is a song sung in this play by a character named Amiens. The song captures the play's central idea: the simple, free forest life is more joyful and honest than the complicated, corrupt life at court with all its ambition, politics, and competition.
examples: Shakespeare's plays are performed all over the world â€” in London's Globe Theatre, in Mumbai's Prithvi Theatre, and in schools across Maharashtra.
'As You Like It' is a comedy â€” it has misunderstandings, disguises, and a happy ending, unlike his tragedies like Hamlet.
The Forest of Arden in the play represents a place of freedom and honest living â€” like India's forest ashrams where saints lived simply.
keyPoints: William Shakespeare (1564â€“1616) â€” greatest English writer, wrote 37 plays
'As You Like It' is a comedy set partly in the Forest of Arden
The forest = freedom from ambition, politics, and corruption
'Under the Greenwood Tree' is sung by character Amiens in the play
The song expresses the play's theme: simple life > ambitious worldly life
concepts.funFact: William Shakespeare was born and died on the same date â€” April 23rd! He was born on April 23, 1564 and died on April 23, 1616. April 23 is now celebrated as World Book Day in his honour!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 20, Pages 79-80, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

concepts.title: Meaning of the Song
concepts.content: The song invites people to come under the greenwood tree (a large, shady tree in the forest) and sing along with the sweet bird's throat â€” meaning to sing as freely and naturally as birds do. The singer says: here, there is no enemy except winter and rough weather. This means: in the forest, the only challenges are natural ones like cold and storms. There are no human enemies â€” no jealousy, competition, backstabbing, false friends, or political rivals. The song paints a picture of a paradise where life is simple, honest, and free. The repeated invitation 'Come hither, come hither, come hither!' (Come here!) is a warm, enthusiastic call to anyone who is tired of the world's complications.
examples: Like a picnic in the forest â€” no homework, no competition, just enjoying nature and singing together.
The 'sweet bird's throat' is a beautiful way of saying â€” sing as freely as a bird, without self-consciousness.
In India, saints like Tukaram and Kabir also preferred simple, forest-like lives over the royal court's complexities â€” the same message as this song.
keyPoints: Come under the greenwood tree â€” come to the forest for simple, free living
Sing to the sweet bird's throat â€” sing as freely and joyfully as birds
No enemy but winter and rough weather â€” no human rivalry, jealousy, or politics
Repeated 'Come hither, come hither, come hither!' â€” enthusiastic, warm invitation
The song = paradise of simple living vs complicated ambitious worldly life
concepts.funFact: Many people who are stressed by city life in India go to forest retreats and eco-villages â€” exactly what Shakespeare's song invites. The Forest Research Institute in Dehradun even has a beautiful campus where people can walk among ancient trees for peace of mind!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 20, Pages 79-80, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

concepts.title: Who is Invited â€” The Free Spirit
concepts.content: The song specifically invites 'who doth ambition shun' â€” those who avoid or reject ambition. Ambition means a strong desire for wealth, power, or fame. The song does not invite just anyone â€” it invites those who have made a conscious choice to step away from the rat race of ambition, competition, and worldly success. These are people who prefer honesty and simplicity over power and wealth. 'Doth' is the old English form of 'does'. So 'who doth ambition shun' = 'whoever avoids ambition'. The song says: if you are that kind of person â€” free-spirited, content, preferring a simple life â€” then come, this forest is for you. The forest is a place for those who are free in spirit.
examples: A person who leaves a high-paying city job to become a farmer or teacher in a village â€” they 'shun ambition' and prefer a simpler life.
India's Vanprastha tradition (third stage of life in Hinduism) where people leave worldly life for the forest â€” the same spirit as this song.
Mahatma Gandhi gave up a successful legal career to live simply â€” a real example of someone who chose to shun ambition.
keyPoints: 'Who doth ambition shun' = whoever avoids/rejects ambition (the rat race)
Ambition = strong desire for wealth, power, fame â€” the song invites those who reject this
The forest is for free spirits â€” people content with simple, honest living
The song does NOT say ambition is always wrong â€” it invites those who CHOOSE simplicity
This is a personal invitation to those whose nature is free and content
concepts.funFact: Today, many young people worldwide are choosing 'downshifting' â€” deliberately choosing less stressful, lower-income jobs to have more free time and happiness. Shakespeare described this choice 400 years ago in 'Under the Greenwood Tree'!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 20, Pages 79-80, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

concepts.title: Old English Words in the Song
concepts.content: Shakespeare wrote around 1600 AD â€” over 400 years ago. The English language has changed a great deal since then. The poem uses several Old English words that are no longer used in modern English. 'Hither' means 'here' â€” 'Come hither' = 'Come here'. 'Doth' means 'does' â€” 'who doth ambition shun' = 'who does shun ambition'. 'I'the' (or 'i' the) means 'in the' â€” a shortened, contracted form. These old words are called archaic words. Reading archaic language helps us understand what English sounded like centuries ago, and also helps us read Shakespeare's original texts more easily. These words may look strange at first, but they are simply older forms of words we already know.
examples: 'Come hither, come hither' = 'Come here, come here' â€” simple once you know the meaning.
'Who doth ambition shun' = 'Who does avoid ambition' â€” 'doth' is just the old form of 'does'.
Like how Marathi has changed over centuries â€” old Marathi texts use different forms of words that are not used in modern Marathi.
keyPoints: 'Hither' = here (old English)
'Doth' = does (old English)
'I'the' = in the (old contraction)
These are called archaic words â€” no longer in common use
Shakespeare's language is 400+ years old, so many words look unfamiliar today
concepts.funFact: Many archaic English words are still used in legal documents in India! Words like 'hereby', 'therein', 'aforesaid' in legal contracts are old English words similar to 'hither' and 'doth' â€” old-fashioned formal English preserved in law!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 20, Pages 79-80, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

concepts.title: Theme â€” Simple Life vs Ambition
concepts.content: The central theme of the song is the contrast between two kinds of life: (1) The ambitious, worldly life â€” full of competition, political games, greed, jealousy, and enemies. (2) The simple, natural life in the forest â€” free, honest, peaceful, with only nature's challenges (winter, rough weather). Shakespeare uses the greenwood tree as a symbol of freedom and natural happiness. The song suggests that true contentment comes not from wealth or power, but from living simply and honestly, in harmony with nature. This theme connects with many Indian philosophical traditions â€” the idea that the 'material world' causes suffering, and simplicity brings peace. The forest represents moksha (liberation) from the cycle of worldly competition.
examples: In the Ramayana, Ram chooses to live in the forest (vanavasa) where his life becomes purer and more heroic than it was in the palace.
India's tribal communities who live in forests and have very few material possessions often report high levels of contentment and community happiness.
The 'Slow Life' movement in modern India encourages people to leave busy cities for quieter, simpler village or forest lifestyles.
keyPoints: Theme: Simple, natural life > ambitious, competitive worldly life
Greenwood tree = symbol of freedom, contentment, natural happiness
Worldly life has human enemies; forest life has only natural ones (winter, weather)
Connects with Indian philosophy: material world causes stress; simplicity brings peace
The song is an invitation to choose inner freedom over outer success
concepts.funFact: The concept of 'Thoreau's Walden' â€” a famous American author who went to live alone in the forest for two years to simplify his life â€” is exactly the experience Shakespeare sings about. People across centuries and cultures have longed for this greenwood tree life!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 20, Pages 79-80, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

test.question: Who wrote the song 'Under the Greenwood Tree'?
test.explanation: William Shakespeare wrote 'Under the Greenwood Tree'. It is a song from his famous comedy 'As You Like It', written around 1599.

test.question: From which play is 'Under the Greenwood Tree' taken?
test.explanation: 'Under the Greenwood Tree' is a song from Shakespeare's comedy 'As You Like It'. The play is set partly in the magical Forest of Arden.

test.question: What does the old English word 'hither' mean?
test.explanation: 'Hither' is an old English word meaning 'here'. 'Come hither' means 'Come here'. It is an archaic word no longer used in modern everyday English.

test.question: What does the old English word 'doth' mean?
test.explanation: 'Doth' is the old English form of 'does'. So 'who doth ambition shun' = 'whoever does shun ambition' in modern English.

test.question: Who is invited in the song to come under the greenwood tree?
options: B) Those who have given up worldly ambition
test.explanation: The song invites 'who doth ambition shun' â€” those who have chosen to give up or avoid worldly ambition, competition, and the rat race. These are free-spirited people who prefer simple living.

test.question: According to the song, what is the only enemy in the forest life?
test.explanation: In the forest, the song says the only enemy is winter and rough weather â€” natural challenges. There are no human enemies like jealousy, competition, or political rivals.

test.question: What does the song invite people to sing to?
options: A) The sound of the river
D) The wind in the trees
test.explanation: The song invites people to 'sing...unto the sweet bird's throat' â€” meaning to sing as freely and naturally as birds do, in harmony with nature.

test.question: What is the main theme of 'Under the Greenwood Tree'?
options: A) The importance of being ambitious and successful
B) The joys of a simple, free, natural life over a life of ambition
C) The dangers of living in the forest
D) How singing improves your voice
test.explanation: The main theme is that a simple, free life in nature is more joyful and peaceful than an ambitious, complicated worldly life. The greenwood tree symbolises freedom and natural contentment.

keyConcepts: William Shakespeare (1564â€“1616) â€” greatest English playwright
'As You Like It' â€” comedy set in Forest of Arden
Song theme: simple forest life vs ambitious worldly life
Invited: those who shun ambition ('who doth ambition shun')
No enemy but winter and rough weather in forest life
Old English words: hither=here, doth=does, i'the=in the
Greenwood tree = symbol of freedom and contentment
commonMisconceptions: Students may think the song is against all ambition â€” it simply says that SOME people choose simplicity and the song invites THEM; it doesn't condemn ambition for everyone.
Old English words look difficult but are simple once explained â€” 'doth', 'hither', 'i'the' just mean 'does', 'here', 'in the'.
The forest in the song is symbolic â€” it represents any life of simplicity, not literally moving to a forest.
Students may confuse 'As You Like It' with other Shakespeare plays â€” it is a COMEDY (happy ending), not a tragedy.
realWorldExamples: India's forest ashrams (like those of Ramana Maharshi or Sri Aurobindo) represent exactly the greenwood tree ideal â€” simple living for inner peace.
India's tribal communities in Maharashtra's Sahyadri hills live close to nature with very few material possessions â€” a real-life greenwood tree existence.
The contrast of ambitious Mumbai city life vs peaceful Konkan village life is a very Maharashtra-specific example of the song's theme.
Gandhian philosophy of simple living and high thinking ('Sade jiyo, uchch vichar karo') perfectly captures the essence of this song.

interactiveElement.title: Vocabulary Flashcards!
interactiveElement.description: Flip each card to reveal the meaning of the word.

cards.back: A figure of speech comparing two unlike things without using 'like' or 'as'
Repetition of the same initial consonant sound in nearby words
A word that has the same or similar meaning as another word

cards.front: What is a 'stanza' in a poem?
cards.back: A group of lines in a poem, similar to a paragraph in prose

textbookExercise.instructions: Memorize these exam-style answers to maximize scoring in textbook-focused assessments.

qaCards.question: Who wrote the song 'Under the Greenwood Tree'?
qaCards.answer: William Shakespeare wrote 'Under the Greenwood Tree'. It is a song from his famous comedy 'As You Like It', written around 1599.

qaCards.question: From which play is 'Under the Greenwood Tree' taken?

qaCards.answer: 'Hither' is an old English word meaning 'here'. 'Come hither' means 'Come here'. It is an archaic word no longer used in modern everyday English.

qaCards.answer: 'Doth' is the old English form of 'does'. So 'who doth ambition shun' = 'whoever does shun ambition' in modern English.

qaCards.question: Who is invited in the song to come under the greenwood tree?
qaCards.answer: The song invites 'who doth ambition shun' â€” those who have chosen to give up or avoid worldly ambition, competition, and the rat race. These are free-spirited people who prefer simple living.

qaCards.answer: In the forest, the song says the only enemy is winter and rough weather â€” natural challenges. There are no human enemies like jealousy, competition, or political rivals.

qaCards.answer: The song invites people to 'sing...unto the sweet bird's throat' â€” meaning to sing as freely and naturally as birds do, in harmony with nature.

qaCards.question: What is the main theme of 'Under the Greenwood Tree'?

longAnswers.question: What does the old English word 'hither' mean?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The old English word 'hither' simply means 'here' in modern English. In the song "Under the Greenwood Tree", the repeated phrase "Come hither" acts as a warm and enthusiastic invitation. It is an archaic word that Shakespeare used because he wrote the play over 400 years ago. Understanding such words helps us appreciate the original beauty of his poetry. For example, when someone says "come hither," they are just inviting you to join them where they are.
keyPoints: 'Hither' is an archaic English word that translates to 'here' in modern language.
It is used in the song as an enthusiastic invitation ("Come hither").
The word reflects the period over 400 years ago when Shakespeare wrote.
It helps convey a welcoming tone to those seeking the simple forest life.

longAnswers.question: What does the old English word 'doth' mean?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The word 'doth' is an old English form of the modern verb 'does'. In Shakespeare's song, the phrase "who doth ambition shun" means "whoever does shun ambition". It is considered an archaic word because it is no longer used in everyday modern English. However, reading words like 'doth' allows us to experience the English language as it was spoken centuries ago. Today, you might still occasionally see such words in very old formal or legal documents.
keyPoints: 'Doth' is the archaic form of the modern verb 'does'.
It appears in the line "who doth ambition shun", referring to someone who avoids ambition.
The word is a reflection of the English language as it was over 400 years ago.
While no longer in everyday use, it adds historical flavour to Shakespeare's poetry.

longAnswers.question: According to the song, what is the only enemy in the forest life?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: According to the song, the only enemies in the forest are "winter and rough weather". This highlights that in a simple natural life, the only challenges people face are natural ones like cold or storms. Unlike the ambitious worldly life at court, there are no human enemies driven by jealousy, greed, or political rivalry. The forest is portrayed as a peaceful paradise where people can live freely and honestly. The focus is on natural survival rather than interpersonal conflict.
keyPoints: The only enemies mentioned in the forest are "winter and rough weather".
The challenges of forest life are entirely natural, not man-made.
There are no human enemies, jealousy, or political rivalries in this simple life.
The forest represents a peaceful paradise free from worldly corruption.

longAnswers.question: What does the song invite people to sing to?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The song invites people to sing "unto the sweet bird's throat", which means to sing as freely and naturally as the birds do. This invitation encourages people to harmonize with nature and let go of their worldly worries. By comparing human singing to a bird's song, Shakespeare emphasizes a life of joy and simple pleasures. It paints a picture of contentment where individuals can express themselves without any self-consciousness. Singing in the forest represents pure, unburdened happiness.
keyPoints: People are invited to sing "unto the sweet bird's throat".
This means singing freely, naturally, and joyfully like birds.
It symbolizes living in harmony with nature and abandoning worldly stress.
The act of singing reflects the pure happiness and contentment of forest life.

longAnswers.question: What is the main theme of 'Under the Greenwood Tree'?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The central theme of "Under the Greenwood Tree" is the contrast between a complicated, ambitious worldly life and a simple, peaceful life in nature. The song suggests that true happiness comes from living honestly and freely, away from the corruption and rivalries of the royal court. By rejecting ambition, individuals can find contentment in the forest, where their only challenges are the weather. The greenwood tree serves as a powerful symbol of this freedom and natural joy. Ultimately, it is an invitation to choose inner peace over worldly success.
keyPoints: The poem contrasts the ambitious worldly life with a simple life in nature.
True happiness and contentment are found in honest, simple living.
The forest offers freedom from human enemies, jealousy, and political corruption.
The greenwood tree symbolizes freedom, natural joy, and inner peace.

longAnswers.question: Who is invited in the song to come under the greenwood tree?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The song explicitly invites those "who doth ambition shun," meaning people who have rejected worldly ambition and the rat race. It is a warm call for free-spirited individuals who seek contentment over wealth or power. These are people who prefer a simple, honest life in harmony with nature rather than dealing with political rivalries. Shakespeare suggests that the forest is a sanctuary for those tired of the complicated royal court. Therefore, only those willing to live freely and peacefully are truly welcome.
keyPoints: The song invites those "who doth ambition shun" or people who reject worldly ambition.
It calls for free-spirited individuals who prioritize contentment over wealth and power.
The forest is presented as a sanctuary away from the complicated, competitive royal court.
The invitation is meant for people seeking a simple, honest life in harmony with nature.

longAnswers.question: What does the greenwood tree symbolize in the song?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The greenwood tree is a powerful symbol of freedom, natural happiness, and an escape from societal pressures. It represents a simpler way of life where individuals can find contentment without wealth or status. Unlike the royal court, which is filled with enemies and ambition, the tree offers shelter and peace. Under its branches, people can sing freely like birds and enjoy pure, unburdened joy. Ultimately, it embodies the ideal of finding inner peace by living in harmony with the natural world.
keyPoints: The tree symbolizes freedom, natural happiness, and an escape from societal pressures.
It represents a simple life where contentment is found without wealth or high status.
The tree offers a peaceful shelter, contrasting sharply with the corrupt and competitive royal court.
It embodies the idea of finding true inner peace by living harmoniously with nature.
